Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Geoscience education for communities impacted by gas drilling in the Marcellus Shale
Award.AbstractNarration: A partnership between the Paleontological Research Institution, the Cornell Department of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences, and Cornell Cooperative Extension is developing a centralized, comprehensive, and objective educational source of scientific information regarding the potential environmental consequences of hydraulic fracturing in the Marcellus Shale, which is under development throughout the Appalachian Basin as a natural gas resource. This RAPID award responds to a dramatic increase in the demand for reliable and neutral scientific information within the affected communities and enables significantly enhanced outreach efforts in south-central NY State, where drilling is expected to commence by late spring 2010. Public interest in this issue is providing an opportunity to raise public Earth System Science Literacy and to develop educational resources and practices that help the public better understand relative risk and how to make evidence-based decisions under uncertainty. Project activities will eventually expand to additional areas of Marcellus drilling, especially in PA and WV, where complementary outreach efforts focused on land-use issues and workforce needs are underway. It is expected that several tens of thousands of individuals will be reached through a combination of direct outreach in community forums and printed materials disseminated through a network of extension agents and web site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Around the nation, slickwater horizontal high-volume hydraulic fracturing (HVHF), or simply “hydrofracking,” of organic-rich shale is yielding tens of trillions of cubic feet of natural gas, while also negatively impacting local water resources, air quality, and ecosystems. To make informed decisions, the general public needs centralized, comprehensive, evidence-based, and impartial sources of scientific information on this topic, reviewing the geology of shale gas, technology of HVHF, and environmental impacts. To meet this need, the project “Geoscience education for communities impacted by gas drilling in the Marcellus Shale” has focused upon providing written materials and presentations in the region of Marcellus Shale drilling (PA, NY, WV, and OH), which has become the most productive shale gas reservoir in the U.S. and one of the largest in the world. The focus of the project has been particularly upon NY, where the project team is based, and where there has been a moratorium on HVHF, with considerable polarized debate and discussion, throughout the duration of the project.  This initiative has been a collaboration among science educators at the Paleontological Research Institution (PRI, and its Museum of the Earth) and scientists and educators at Cornell University (the Cornell Department of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences and Cornell Cooperative Extension).

The broader objectives have been to foster Earth system science literacy, taking advantage of the public interest in HVHF in the Marcellus Shale as a “teachable moment,” to create accessible, scientifically accurate resources and programs around energy transitions. An important role of the publications and presentations has been highlighting the complexity of factors to consider in analyzing energy development options, without advocating for or against specific political or policy positions. Since all large scale energy production methods have substantial negative environmental impacts, the outeach also suggests that the most direct approach to lowering impacts is to find ways to use less energy.

This project has resulted in (1) a series of “Marcellus Papers,” and (2) the book, The Science Beneath the Surface: A Very Short Guide to the Marcellus Shale (252 pp.), published in October of 2013. The Marcellus Papers are a series of ten individual articles, each reviewing a specific issue such as HVHF and water use, seismicity, and radioactivity. These papers are available as downloadable pdfs from PRI’s Museum of the Earth website www.museumoftheearth.org/marcellusshale. The book is a compilation, rewriting, and extension of the Marcellus Papers, with new chapters on topics such as greenhouse gas emissions, risk analysis, and teaching about shale gas issues.

The project has included dozens of public talks, conference presentations, and educator workshops. PRI and Cornell hosted a conference in Ithaca in March 2013 (co-supported by complementary NSF grant 1035078) involving more than fifty educators from throughout the Marcellus Shale region, for educator professional development and collaboration.  

All of the resources from the project are available at or linked to from the PRI website. The website contains:

  • the Marcellus Papers and information about the Science Beneath the Surface book;
  • information about the “Best Practices in Marcellus Shale Education Conference,” including links to presentations at the conference;
  • The Science Beneath the Surface blog by PRI staff, including a link to the “Prezi,” There’s No Such Thing as a Free Megawatt (bit.ly/MarcellusGateway);
